channel.title: Posts on Aryaman Arora

item.title: The Hittite problem
item.description: How do we interpret neural networks? We should start by comparing it to the geopolitical situation of early Indo-European Anatolia.

item.title: Me and Research
item.description: Looking back at my research journey in NLP after getting into a Ph.D. program.

item.title: Some intuitions about transformers
item.description: I've been thinking about transformers a lot recently.

item.title: Some CCG derivations in Hindi
item.description: Learned about Combinatory Categorial Grammar in class, so I tried to apply it to Hindi.

item.title: NAACL 2022
item.description: NAACL was the best conference experience I've ever had, no doubt about it.

item.title: A machine-learned syntactic tagset?
item.description: Messing with the Kitaev et al. (2022) parser.

item.title: Secret verb forms in Hindi
item.description: There are some strange verb forms in Hindi that I haven't seen described in any grammar or paper. I've collected some of them here.

item.title: The -kk- verbal extension in Indo-Aryan
item.description: After the fragmentation of Sanskrit, one of the innovative features that developed across the Indo-Aryan language family are the "pleonastic" suffixes, including (but not limited to) -kk-, -ḍ-, -r-, -l(l)-, and nominal diminutives -ka- (m.) and -ikā- (f.). Pleonastic means serving no semantic purpose; basically, the consensus has been that these suffixes merely served as phonological extensions to distinguish words after the collapse of many phonotactic distinctions from Sanskrit to Middle Indo-Aryan.

item.title: *ll in Indo-Aryan
item.description: Some notes on the development of *ll in Indo-Aryan.

item.title: Reflexive causatives in Hindi
item.description: A new kind of language change?

item.description: Gloss of the song by Muhammad Masood.

item.title: Greater Magadha
item.description: Notes on the book by Johannes Bronkhorst.

item.title: Hindi is not Sanskrit: Phonetics and Phonology
item.description: Hindi is not "exactly like Sanskrit" despite what some nonsensical claims say.

item.title: Bhāṣācitra
item.description: Recently, I’ve been working on mapping the languages of South Asia by organising the scholarly work that has been done on individual varieties.

item.title: New Indo-Aryan conservatisms
item.description: This is a list of Indo-Aryan lexical items whch can be traced to Indo-European yet have no preserved Sanskrit intermediaries.

item.title: Why Linguistics?
item.description: This is a question I’ve been dealing with ever since I went down this academic path, and one that I think I will continue to grapple with for a long time: what is the point of studying linguistics?

item.title: ACL 2020
item.description: ACL 2020 was the most exciting event in my life so far as a proto-computational linguist. This was my first conference, and my first published research paper.

item.title: Hindi adpositions
item.description: These are just some notes about Hindi SNACS that I wanted to be publicly available. I would use Google Docs, but they don't have good support for interlinear glosses. I would use Xposition, but I'm not really sure what the best place for it is there.
